 Ok, here's a thought. If we assume that truth is objective, than we can also assume that it's consistant. That which is true stays true. For example, universal constants stay constant, and if it's true that I'm sitting here right now, than it will always be true that at this moment in time I'm sitting here. 
 
 Now, we know that perception can be faulty, so simply saying "I perceive such and such" doesn't mean it's necessarily true. So for any given statement, taken in isolation, it's extremely difficult to say if it's true or not. However, there's no need to take statements in isolation. If objective truths exist, than they must co-exist. And to co-exist and remain true, they can't contradict each other. So, if we can develop a body of statements that are known to be true, or at least we're pretty sure they're true, we can compare any new statements to that body. If it contradicts one or more, than it's probably false. If it doesn't, than it could be true. Note that this is only a negative test. It can show something to be false, but it can't prove it true.
